abstract: The Capitol attacks ruptured their mutual trust. In the weeks before Brian Mock’s sentencing, could he mend the divide with his son A.J.?
lead_paragraph: The trial was over and the verdict was in, but Brian Mock, 44, kept going back through the evidence, trying to make his case to the one person whose opinion he valued most. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Wisconsin next to his son, 21-year-old A.J. Mock, and opened a video on his laptop. He leaned into the screen and traced his finger over the image of the U.S. Capitol building, looked through clouds of tear gas and smoke and then pointed toward the center of a riotous crowd.
headline: A Jan. 6 Defendant Pleads His Case to the Son Who Turned Him In
keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Attacks on Police;Mock, Brian (1979- );Mock, AJ (2002- );Wisconsin;Content Type: Personal Profile;Presidential Election of 2020;Voter Fraud (Election Fraud);Rumors and Misinformation;Conspiracy Theories;internal-sub-only;internal-great-read;audio-neutral-informative;audio-neutral-suspenseful

abstract: In Pennsylvania and elsewhere, A.I. is being applied to the nation’s aging infrastructure. Is that wise?
lead_paragraph: In Pennsylvania, where 13 percent of the bridges have been classified as structurally deficient, engineers are using artificial intelligence to create lighter concrete blocks for new construction. Another project is using A.I. to develop a highway wall that can absorb noise from cars — and some of the greenhouse gas emissions that traffic releases as well.
headline: New Tool for Building and Fixing Roads and Bridges: Artificial Intelligence

abstract: While most of Europe’s leagues engage in a Sisyphean quest to source as much money as possible, Sweden has chosen a different model. But its rewards come with risk.
lead_paragraph: The warning sounded over and over, first in Swedish and then in English. A fire had been detected. Please evacuate the stadium. The players left the field. Outside, fire crews were arriving. But in the stands, as a thick cloud of smoke wreathed and coiled in the floodlights, nobody moved. The fans were going to make the game happen by sheer force of will.
headline: Swedish Soccer Prioritized Fans Over Finances. Now, Business Is Booming.
keywords: Soccer;Fans (Persons);Finances;Allsvenskan (Swedish Soccer League);Sweden;Elfsborg (Soccer Team);Malmo (Soccer Team)

abstract: Mathias Énard’s new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” considers the jumble of life in a variety of stories and styles.
lead_paragraph: To fully appreciate what Mathias Énard is up to in his new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” it helps to know about the 16th-century French literary genius François Rabelais and his bawdy five-volume masterpiece, “Gargantua and Pantagruel.” A tale of giants who roam the French countryside having drunken adventures and upsetting social norms, Rabelais’s work has been a wellspring of laughter through much of Western literary history, inspiring writers for centuries, though these days he is probably more referred to than read.
headline: A Trip to the French Countryside, and Through Time
keywords: Books and Literature;Enard, Mathias;The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers' Guild (Book)

abstract: Our crime columnist recommends four newly published books.
lead_paragraph: There’s a mordant theme to this month’s column; in three of the four books, dark humor undercuts despair and sardonic wit compensates for failure. Nowhere are these traits more on display than in DEATH OF THE RED RIDER (Pushkin Vertigo, 396 pp., paperback, $16.95), the second appearance of Yulia Yakovleva’s Stalin-era detective, Vasily Zaitsev, who goes about the ordinary business of solving murders while communities around him in 1930s Russia are purged and exiled en masse.
headline: ‘Murder’s Easy. We Did Something Much Worse.’
keywords: Books and Literature;genre-books-mystery;Death of the Red Rider: A Leningrad Confidential (Book);Yakovleva, Yulia;Kemp, Ruth Ahmedzai;Deus X (Book);Jones, Stephen Mack;Skeletons in the Closet (Book);Manchette, Jean-Patrick;Waters, Alyson (Translator);Twilight Falls (Book);Black, Juneau (Pseudonym);Nagel, Sharon (Author);Cole, Jocelyn (Author)

abstract: In the third installment of an essay series on literature and faith, Ayana Mathis explores how writers have grappled with one of theology’s oldest conundrums.
lead_paragraph: In the church of my childhood, we believed God’s angels battled demons in a war for our souls. This was not a metaphor. We were Pentecostals, though not strictly and not always. We weren’t picky about denomination; what mattered was belief in the redeeming blood of Christ, in the Bible literally interpreted and in God’s endless love. And evil. We believed in evil.
headline: Why Do Evil and Suffering Exist? Religion Has One Answer, Literature Another.
keywords: Books and Literature;Religion and Belief;Writing and Writers;Baldwin, James (1924-87);Go Tell It on the Mountain (Book);Hulse, S M;Black River (Book);Otsuka, Julie;When the Emperor Was Divine (Book)

abstract: The author of the “Slow Horses” series says he relates more with failures. With millions of books sold and the third season of the series airing next month, he may have to wrap his head around success.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Mick Herron’s rickety literary career looked to be falling apart. None of his novels had sold more than a few hundred copies, and “Slow Horses,” the first book in his acidly funny series about a band of misfits in the British intelligence services, had performed so badly that its sequel, “Dead Lions,” could not find a British publisher.

abstract: Silicon Valley has immersed us in an expensive, pervasive and perennially annoying type of automated capitalism.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending. As I’ve subscribed to more apps and streaming platforms, significant sums of my money tend to drift away each month without my ever thinking about it. It’s as if it were a tax being taken out of my paycheck, one spent on something silly or indulgent like a subscription box of international snacks instead of — I don’t know — basic public infrastructure.
headline: The Sneaky Sticker Shock of Subscription Culture

abstract: After my daughter’s death, I have been approaching this holiday with trepidation.
lead_paragraph: Grieving parents like me are told to gird themselves for anniversaries and holidays, for birthdays and religious events. We’re advised to plan for days associated with joy. We consider exit strategies. We talk about how the markers of civil religion and religious observance are harder for us, now that we no longer exist exactly inside society, but run alongside it, observing. Each holiday centered on family is now barbed.
headline: The Empty Seat at Our Thanksgiving Table

abstract: Popular with the Czech public for quietly subverting the aristocracy, he served twice as foreign minister and ran for president in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Karel Schwarzenberg, a Czech prince who twice served as his country’s foreign minister, played a key role in the Velvet Revolution and quietly subverted aristocratic expectations, died shortly after midnight on Nov. 12 in Vienna. He was 85.
headline: Karel Schwarzenberg, Renegade Czech Prince and Politician, Dies at 85
keywords: Schwarzenberg, Karel;Deaths (Obituaries);Czechoslovakia;Politics and Government;Havel, Vaclav

abstract: Sam Altman’s abrupt ouster from OpenAI highlighted deep divisions in the A.I. world and culminated in his surprise return to the start-up he founded.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt ouster of Sam Altman on Friday as chief executive of OpenAI, one of the world’s most prominent A.I. companies and  the maker of ChatGPT, set off a head-spinning series of twists  that culminated late Tuesday with Mr. Altman’s reinstatement at the company he founded and pledges to overhaul the way OpenAI is run.
headline: What Happened in the World of Artificial Intelligence?
keywords: Appointments and Executive Changes;Artificial Intelligence;Boards of Directors;OpenAI Labs;Altman, Samuel H;Brockman, Greg

abstract: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour broke records in North America, but has faced tragedy and mishaps during a three-day stretch of concerts in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift was welcomed to Brazil on Thursday by a projection that made the world-famous Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro appear as if it were clad in a T-shirt similar to the one she wore in her “You Belong With Me” music video and was decorated with the names of Brazilian states and symbols from her songs.
headline: After Eras Tour Triumphs, Taylor Swift Finds Trouble in Brazil
keywords: Pop and Rock Music;Swift, Taylor;Heat and Heat Waves;Fans (Persons);Rio de Janeiro (Brazil);Deaths (Fatalities)

abstract: Rarely has the U.S. government so depended on the technology provided by a single technologist with views that it has so publicly declared repugnant.
lead_paragraph: The White House denounced Elon Musk on Friday for “abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate,” for his endorsement of what an administration spokesman called a “hideous lie” about Jews.
headline: The White House May Condemn Musk, but the Government Is Addicted to Him
keywords: Musk, Elon;United States Politics and Government;Private Spaceflight;Biden, Joseph R Jr;United States Defense and Military Forces;Defense Contracts;Starlink Satellite Constellation (SpaceX);Space Exploration Technologies Corp;Satellites;Defense Department;Anti-Semitism

abstract: She helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Sunday in Plains, Ga. She was 96.
headline: Rosalynn Carter, First Lady and a Political Partner, Dies at 96
keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Carter, Rosalynn;Carter, Jimmy;Presidential Election of 1980;Georgia;Women's Rights;Mental Health and Disorders;First Ladies (US);United States Politics and Government

abstract: But “takemehome,” a look at isolation by Dimitri Chamblas in collaboration with the musician Kim Gordon, fades into its own shadows at NYU Skirball.
lead_paragraph: The dance started — or seemed to start — with people walking onto the stage before finding a spot and lying down. The bright, blisteringly white lights made the view murky, yet through the haze random bodies were stretched out on backs and sides, utterly limp. Above them was a suspended zeppelin: Imagine a giant balloon of a baked potato floating over 34th Street in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
headline: It Seemed to Have It All: 9 Dancers, 5 Guitars, 5 Amps
keywords: Dancing;Chamblas, Dimitri;Gordon, Kim (1953- );Skirball Center for the Performing Arts

abstract: In amassing 3,611 victories, he rode a long shot, Proud Clarion, to victory in the 1967 Kentucky Derby. The next year at Churchill Downs, he saw victory nullified.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Ussery, a Hall of Fame jockey whose 3,611 victories included the 1960 Preakness Stakes and the 1967 Kentucky Derby, but who saw victory at Churchill Downs snatched away the next year when his horse was disqualified after the race, died on Thursday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 88.
headline: Bobby Ussery, Jockey Who Saw Triumph and Dismay, Dies at 88
keywords: Horse Racing;Kentucky Derby;Deaths (Obituaries);Ussery, Bobby (1935-2023)

abstract: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.
headline: Premature Babies Are Treated After Evacuation From Al-Shifa Hospital
keywords: Hospitals;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Premature Babies;Evacuations and Evacuees;Gaza Strip

abstract: Plus: A woman’s unconventional escape in India.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four days after the Israeli military stormed the biggest hospital in the Gaza Strip, the World Health Organization described the complex as a “death zone” where several patients had died because medical services had been shut down.
headline: Monday Briefing: Babies Evacuated From Al-Shifa
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas;Al Shifa Hospital (Gaza Strip);Hamas;Israel;Gaza Strip;Bedbugs;Artificial Intelligence;OpenAI Labs;Altman, Samuel H

abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott threw his support behind the former president in the Republican presidential primary at an event near the southern border.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday in an appearance near the southern border, echoing Mr. Trump’s talk about an existential crisis of illegal immigration.
headline: Texas Governor Endorses Trump, Lauding His Border Policies
keywords: Trump, Donald J;Abbott, Gregory W (1957- );Illegal Immigration;Presidential Election of 2024;Republican Party

abstract: Disagreements over the board’s makeup appear to have muddled negotiations. Mr. Altman was forced out as chief executive by the company’s board on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Talks at OpenAI to bring back Sam Altman, the artificial intelligence start-up’s recently ousted chief executive, continued into Sunday evening but there were disagreements over the makeup of the company’s board of directors, according to two people familiar with the discussions.
headline: Talks to Bring Sam Altman Back to OpenAI Stretch Through Weekend
keywords: Boards of Directors;Appointments and Executive Changes;Computers and the Internet;Artificial Intelligence;OpenAI Labs;Altman, Samuel H;Hurd, Will

abstract: The British news media reported on Sunday that he was questioned in connection with three sex offenses.
lead_paragraph: The British police questioned Russell Brand, the comedian, actor and YouTuber, in relation to three allegations that he had committed sexual offenses, according to British news reports.
headline: London Police Question Russell Brand About Past Allegations
keywords: Brand, Russell;Sex Crimes;London (England)

abstract: Sam Ezersky leaves us in a state of disarray.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
headline: The Shape of a Rainbow
keywords: Crossword Puzzles;Games

abstract: President Biden has no plans for a lavish public celebration when he turns 81 on Monday, even as Democrats search for a strategy to assuage voters’ concerns about his age by next year’s election.
lead_paragraph: For many of a certain age, there comes a point when marking yet another birthday, taking note of yet another passage of the calendar, is not greeted with the same enthusiasm it once was. And that’s for people who are not even running for president.
headline: For an Aging President, a Birthday With a Bite
keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;Presidents and Presidency (US);United States Politics and Government;Democratic Party;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Trump, Donald J;Age, Chronological

abstract: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Argentines on Sunday chose Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who has drawn comparisons to Donald J. Trump, as their next president, a lurch to the right for a nation struggling under an economic crisis and a sign of the enduring strength of the global far right.
headline: Argentina Elects Javier Milei in Victory for Far Right
keywords: ARGENTINA;Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right;Economic Conditions and Trends;Elections;Milei, Javier;Massa, Sergio (1972- )

abstract: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Four days after it was seized by Israeli troops, the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital has become a “death zone,” the World Health Organization said, as 31 premature babies in extremely precarious health there were evacuated on Sunday.
headline: Infants Moved From ‘Death Zone’ Hospital That Israel Says Was Hamas Hideout
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Premature Babies;Civilian Casualties;Al Shifa Hospital (Gaza Strip);Palestinians;Gaza Strip;Kidnapping and Hostages;Israel;Rafah (Gaza Strip);Hamas;Houthis;Hospitals
